content.title: Factory status May 2024 (TPM/Eng)
content.visibleText:
Factory status May 2024 (TPM/Eng)

Summary

Slot Delivery
In numbers:
15 commit goals: 6 completed, 7 on track, 2 off track (of which, one is at high risk)
7 stretch goals: 2 deprioritized, 3 on track, 2 off track
8 new goals (added during Q2): 1 completed, 3 on track, 4 off track (of which, two are at high risk)
Why are we adding new goals when not all commit/stretch goals are green?
Higher priority defense goals that were not planned (for the case of Influitive)
Project completing early than planned, leaving available capacity (e.g. Jigsaw)
New acquisitions (the case of Stratifyd)

What went well:
Responded well to changing BU priorities - took over and made progress on many new goals
Turned better in meeting commitments - we will deliver all but one of the Commit goals in Q2
Did much around the Messenger slot - delivered more than planned

What did not go well:
Customer adoption is low and remains low (details below)

Maintenance
Maintenance had a great month. We have already delivered 88% of our Q2 orders (goal: 20 tickets per SE7), and we are on track to overdeliver for all BUs.
We removed 62% of our backlog in Q2 so far and are on track to eliminate our backlog in Q2.

You can find the delivery scorecard and the burndown charts at the bottom of the document.

Early Customer Adoption
We added the preliminary scorecard to projects in 3 BUs (ignite, Jigsaw, Influitive). We made progress, but results are below what we would have wanted and usage/activity remains low:
Messenger: of 20 customers, 4 customers showed interest, none has concrete upgrade plans (many want to wait until the new version is proven stable or are mid-upgrade with older versions)
Jive Security: of 12 customers, 3 are interested in upgrading.
Jive Cloud AI Copilot: 2 customers actively using it, 7 have it enabled, most have it disabled

What went well:
Focus on customer problems - conducted calls to understand their problems (for projects in early stages), help them use the product (for AI features), or get them to upgrade (for defense projects)
Focus on business value: analyzing usage (e.g. Jive Copilot Usage Report) and acting upon it

What did not go well:
We started without a clear framework and spent time aligning expectations, navigating our org, or doing work that we did actually believe to be in our a scope
We focused on a subset of customers which we believed to be more interested and got low response rates. We should have contacted all customers to increase the size of the early adoption pool.

windows.title: TPM Slot - Early Adoption Service - Google Docs

content.title: TPM Slot - Early Adoption Service
content.visibleText:
Background

The Product Manager (PM) service within the TPM group exists to prove the business value of offense projects by driving early adoption, getting customer feedback involving, and validating that the business got value out of their investment in the slot. The goal is to get the product enhancements in the hands of engaged early adopter customers.

Approach

What is in the scope of the PM early adoption service

Early Involvement: PMs get involved in the early stages of the project to deeply understand the customer problem and validate the solution.
Selecting Early Adopters: For each slot, the PMs will reach out broadly to the entire applicable customer base and identify the willing early adopters who want to engage.
Continuous Engagement: As the feature is being built and released in small iterations, PMs will work with selected customers and collect customer feedback that will guide the implementation. They will ensure that customers are successful in using the new features/updates and demonstrate the business value delivered by the slot.
Improving Outreach: Over time, PMs will improve their outreach, playbook and techniques to convert more of the overall customer base into engaged early adopters. However, their scope will remain limited to customers who willingly opt-in to participate.

What is out of scope

Driving adoption from the remaining unengaged customers. The PMs will provide a clear list of which subset of customers they are focused on so there is no ambiguity about the split of responsibilities with the BU.
Defense projects - security upgrades or certifications do not need an early adoption service, just proper announcements and coordination of the install (e.g., distributing binaries for on-prem or install/release for SaaS products)
Release process coordination - e.g., distributing binaries for on-prem or install/release for SaaS products, paperwork, marketing announcements, project managing the various involved parties (CS, Eng, BU, customer), etc

Service prerequisites

Autonomy: PMs need the autonomy to contact and work with customers but all communication plans and messaging will be shared for review with BUs. Throughout the project, they will position their work as focused on the slot business goal, to avoid any confusion with the responsibility of the BU PMs or CSMs.
Customer Contacts: BUs will provide the customer list and known contacts. In addition, PMs will attempt to navigate the organization or use available information to identify the most relevant stakeholders.

Process

To ensure the successful early adoption of AI features and enhancements, the AI Adoption Product Manager (PM) service will follow structured and methodical approaches to engage the right stakeholders and ensure that the AI solutions are effectively integrated into the customer's operational processes.

content.title: Factory status May 2024 (TPM/Eng)
content.layoutDescription: Document layout with text and bullet points
content.visibleText:
Factory status May 2024 (TPM/Eng)

File Edit View Insert Format Tools Extensions Help

Menus

100% Normal text Calibri

Outline

Factory status April 2024 (TPM/Eng)

Summary

Kanban Slots
Jigsaw (1 slot)
IgniteTech #1: Security
IgniteTech #2: Copilot
IgniteTech Maintenance
GFI (1 slot)
Influitive (2 slots)
Stratifyd (1 slot)
Crossover (1 slot)
Applied AI (1 slot)
Telco (3 slots + 1 Ops slot)
TPM only slots (1 slot)

Maintenance Delivery scorecard
Burndown charts - road to zero...
All BUs
IgniteTech
CopperTree
Jigsaw
Influitive
You can find the delivery scorecard and the burndown charts at the bottom of the document.

Early Customer Adoption
The PM service was added in May to 3 slots. We made progress, but results are below what we would have wanted and usage/activity remains low:
Messenger: of 20 customers, 4 customers showed interest, none has concrete upgrade plans (many want to wait until the new version is proven stable or are mid-upgrade with older versions)
Jive Security: of 12 customers, 3 are interested in upgrading
Jive Cloud AI Copilot: 2 customers actively using it, 7 have it enabled, others have it disabled
Influitive AI features: outreach started recently

What went well:
Focus on customer problems - conducted calls to understand their problems (for projects in early stages), help them use the product (for AI features), or get them to upgrade (for defense projects)
Focus on business value: analyzing usage (e.g., Jive Copilot Usage Report) and acting upon it
What did not go well:
We started without a clear framework and spent a time aligning expectations, navigating our org, or doing work that we did actually believe to be in our scope
We focused on a subset of customers which we believed to be more interested and got low response rates. We should have contacted all customers to increase the size of the early adoption pool.
Long upgrade cycles for hosted projects (Messenger, Jive HQ) make it impossible to demonstrate customer value during the quarter.

Improvements: we are fixing this by defining the service
TPM Slot - Early Adoption Service. . .
